qas.question: What enables videoconferencing to connect three or more remote points?
What is one type of MCU bridge?
In what way can an MCU be characterized?

answers.text: the number of simultaneous calls it can handle

qas.question: What feature enables an MCU to allow for multiple parties to be seen on screen at the same time?
Where can an MCU be embedded?

plausible_answers.text: by means of a Multipoint Control Unit (MCU)

qas.question: What makes videoconferencing between Continuous Presence possible?

plausible_answers.text: the number of simultaneous calls it can handle

qas.question: What is one thing that characterizes an ISDN?
What feature lets more than one person participate in sequence?

plausible_answers.text: pure software, and others which are a combination of hardware and software.

qas.question: What are remote points made of?
What is one type of simultaneous call that acts as a bridge?

context: Simultaneous videoconferencing among three or more remote points is possible <b5_0>by means of a <a0_0>Multipoint Control Unit (MCU)<b5_0/><a0_0/>. This is a bridge that interconnects calls from several sources (in a similar way to the audio conference call). All parties call the MCU, or the MCU can also call the parties which are going to participate, in sequence. There are MCU bridges for <a1_0><b9_0>IP<b9_0/><a1_0/> and ISDN-based videoconferencing. There are MCUs which are <b8_0>pure software, and others which are a combination of hardware and software.<b8_0/> An MCU is characterised according to <a2_0><b6_0>the number of simultaneous calls it can handle<b6_0/><a2_0/>, its ability to conduct transposing of data rates and protocols, and features such as <a3_0><b7_0>Continuous Presence<b7_0/><a3_0/>, in which multiple parties can be seen on-screen at once. MCUs can be stand-alone hardware devices, or they can be embedded into <a4_0>dedicated videoconferencing units<a4_0/>.
